results.title: Proper winter clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Skiers, hikers and other winter outdoor people learn quickly that it is not how much you have on but what you wear and how you wear it. this film provides the necessary clues to keeping you warm during outdoor travel in winter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman Keziere, James McCormick and Moreland-Latchford Productions

results.title: Proper summer bush clothing
results.creator_credit: Norman Keziere, Hugh Moreland and Moreland-Latchford Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Survival in the Wilderness”.
Two boys head off on a fishing trip, one wearing correct clothing, and the other, ordinary light summer weight slacks and shirt. As the film progresses, the viewer sees that proper clothing is essential to one’s comfort and well-being when camping out.

results.title: Propaganda: resource material from WW1 and WW2.
results.brief_description: This video presents black and white propaganda footage from WW1 and WW2. Part 1 presents excerpts from World War I propaganda in Germany and Australia. Shows early animation/political cartoons by Harry Julius and an excerpt from a Charlie Chaplin film “The Liberty Bond”. Part 2 presents excerpts from World War II propaganda in Australia, Germany and Britain. Includes excerpts by directors Leni Riefenstahl, Humphrey Jennings, Harry Watt and Karl Ritter. The success of cinema propaganda was well established by World War Two. In Germany, Goebbel’s Ministry for National Enlightenment and Propaganda, Britain had its Ministry of Information, in the USA film propaganda was only one part of the total propaganda picture and in Australia we had the Commonwealth Dept. of Information which was responsible for official propaganda and news items.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.2
results.brief_description: Led by Debra Smith and Helen Sutton, this seminar presentation video aims at teaching how to achieving total accuracy in written communication. This volume concentrates on: a basic review of sentence structure; how to fix run-on sentences; subject/verb agreement rules; noun/pronoun agreement rules; who vs. whom, me vs. myself; essential rules for using commas; use of semicolons; dashes and parentheses; and when to use quotations.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.1
results.brief_description: This live video seminar presentation with Debra Smith and Helen Sutton begins with a one-page pre-test to determine your current proofreading accuracy. By the end of the program you’ll be able to see and measure your improvement! Some of the skills learned include: spotting common typographical errors; how to correct writing without changing the meaning; overcoming monotony and staying alert when proofreading; creating distance from your work so you can coorect your own errors; how to use proofreader’s marks for consistency and time saving and how to stay alert and accurate.

results.title: Promoting pupil adjustment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Planning for Teaching”.
Presents actual case studies to show how a secondary school teacher helps pupils to adjust socially. Presents in considerable detail he cases of two boys, Bill, a shy newcomer who is encouraged when interest si shown in his outside activities; and Fred, who has developed unsocial behaviour patterns. Summarizes the cases of two other boys who lack confidence.

results.title: Projekt No. 6
results.brief_description: This guide to research and access to local video artist’s work is intended as an important resource for all curator’s, galleries, students and art lovers with a desire to better understand and appreciate a thriving cultural medium. Contains artworks which have been shown in a gallery context from established, mid career and emerging artists from Australia. The artists included on this tape are: Kate Murphy, Lyndal Jones, David Noonan, Simon Trevaks, Alex Gawronski and Monika Tichacek. Sponsored by the City of Melbourne, The Victorian College of the Arts and the Kings Artist Run Space.
